name: Posterior Dominant Rhythm (PDR)
notes: PDR frequency matures with age; absent PDR in wakefulness may indicate diffuse dysfunction.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: OIRDA is slower (1–3 Hz) and intermittent, while PDR is faster (8–13 Hz) and continuous
Eye blink artifact is frontally maximal and synchronous with eye movements; PDR is posterior and attenuates with eye opening
Drowsy slowing is slower (theta/delta) and diffuse; PDR is faster (alpha) and posterior

clinicalContext.syndromicRelevance: Normal pattern; absence may indicate encephalopathy

abretPearl: PDR frequency increases with age: 6–8 Hz in children, 8–13 Hz in adults. Absent PDR in wakefulness suggests diffuse dysfunction.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF (>0.5 Hz) may attenuate PDR; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in referential montages (average reference); bipolar may show phase reversals
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Requires relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed; disappears with eye opening or alertness

name: Mu Rhythm
reactivity: blocked by movement or intention to move
notes: Not epileptiform; important not to misinterpret as focal spikes.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Mu rhythm blocks with movement; focal spikes do not. Mu is arch-shaped and rhythmic; spikes are sharp and isolated.

abretPearl: Mu rhythm is blocked by movement or intention to move. This reactivity distinguishes it from epileptiform activity.

eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in central electrodes (C3, C4, Cz); referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Present during wakefulness; blocked by movement

name: Wicket Spikes
clinical_correlation: Benign temporal variant without epileptiform significance
notes: High-yield ABRET point: wicket spikes lack a following slow wave and occur in trains.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Epileptiform sharp waves have aftergoing slow waves and disrupt background; wicket spikes lack slow waves and do not disrupt background
Epileptiform spikes are isolated or in brief bursts with slow waves; wicket spikes occur in trains without slow waves

abretPearl: Wicket spikes lack aftergoing slow waves and do not disrupt background rhythm. This is the key distinguishing feature from epileptiform activity.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may smooth the arc shape
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in temporal chain (F7–T3–T5 or F8–T4–T6); referential montages may show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Most common during drowsiness and light sleep (N2)

name: 3 Hz Generalized Spike-and-Wave
morphology: Spike followed by slow wave complexes
notes: Abrupt onset and offset; correlates with clinical absence events.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: 3 Hz GSW is faster (3 Hz) and regular; slow spike-and-wave is slower (2 Hz) and irregular, associated with Lennox-Gastaut
Photic driving is time-locked to flash rate and occipital; 3 Hz GSW is generalized, frontally predominant, and not time-locked

clinicalContext.syndromicRelevance: Childhood absence epilepsy, juvenile absence epilepsy

abretPearl: 3 Hz GSW shows abrupt onset and offset, is enhanced by hyperventilation, and correlates with clinical absence events. The 3 Hz frequency is characteristic.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in referential montages; bipolar may show phase reversals
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Enhanced by hyperventilation; may be present in wakefulness or drowsiness

name: Hypsarrhythmia
morphology: Chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes
duration: Continuous pattern, more prominent in sleep
notes: High-yield ABRET pattern; associated with developmental regression and spasms.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Hypsarrhythmia has chaotic high-amplitude slow waves WITH multifocal spikes; diffuse slowing lacks spikes
Hypsarrhythmia is continuous chaotic pattern; multifocal spikes are discrete events

abretPearl: Hypsarrhythmia is characterized by chaotic, high-amplitude slow waves with multifocal spikes. It is pathognomonic for infantile spasms (West syndrome).

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high LFF may mask slow components
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in referential montages to show diffuse nature
eegSettingsSensitivity.sensitivity: May require lower sensitivity due to high amplitude
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: More prominent in sleep; may attenuate in REM

name: Lambda Waves
reactivity: seen during visual scanning; disappear with eye closure
clinical_correlation: Normal occipital variant during visual scanning
notes: Lambda waves are positive occipital sharp transients seen during visual scanning.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Lambda waves occur during visual scanning; POSTS occur during sleep
Lambda waves are positive and disappear with eye closure; epileptiform spikes are negative and persist

abretPearl: Lambda waves are positive occipital sharp transients that appear during visual scanning and disappear with eye closure. This reactivity distinguishes them from epileptiform activity.

eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in occipital electrodes (O1, O2); referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Present during visual scanning; disappear with eye closure

name: Rhythmic Mid-Temporal Theta (RMTD)
notes: Rhythmic mid-temporal theta is a benign variant seen during drowsiness.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: RMTD is rhythmic and symmetric; pathologic temporal slowing is irregular and asymmetric
RMTD is rhythmic theta; spikes are sharp and isolated

abretPearl: RMTD is rhythmic, symmetric, and occurs during drowsiness. It lacks the irregularity and asymmetry of pathologic temporal slowing.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high LFF may attenuate
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in temporal chain (T3, T4); referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Most common during drowsiness and light sleep

name: Benign Epileptiform Transients of Sleep (BETS)
notes: BETS are small sharp spikes seen during drowsiness and light sleep.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: BETS lack aftergoing slow waves; epileptiform spikes have slow waves
BETS are isolated small spikes; wicket spikes occur in trains

abretPearl: BETS are small sharp spikes that lack aftergoing slow waves. This distinguishes them from epileptiform activity.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may smooth spikes
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in temporal chain; referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Most common during drowsiness and light sleep

name: Focal Spikes (Temporal)
morphology: Sharp waves with aftergoing slow waves
duration: Brief, isolated or in brief bursts
notes: Focal temporal spikes are the most common epileptiform pattern in adults.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Focal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and disrupt background; wicket spikes lack slow waves and do not disrupt background
Focal spikes have aftergoing slow waves; BETS lack slow waves

abretPearl: Focal temporal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and may disrupt background rhythm. This distinguishes them from benign variants.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in temporal chain; referential montages show field better

name: Focal Spikes (Frontal)
morphology: Sharp waves with aftergoing slow waves
duration: Brief, isolated or in brief bursts
notes: Frontal spikes are common in frontal lobe epilepsy.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Frontal spikes have aftergoing slow waves; mu rhythm is arch-shaped and blocks with movement

abretPearl: Frontal spikes have aftergoing slow waves and may disrupt background. They are enhanced by sleep.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in frontal electrodes; referential montages show field better

name: Polyspikes
reactivity: may be enhanced by photic stimulation
notes: Polyspikes are multiple spikes in rapid succession, often associated with myoclonic seizures.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Polyspikes are multiple spikes without slow waves; spike-and-wave has slow waves after spikes

abretPearl: Polyspikes are multiple spikes in rapid succession without slow waves. They are characteristic of myoclonic epilepsy.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high HFF may attenuate spikes
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: May be enhanced by photic stimulation

name: Slow Spike-and-Wave (2 Hz)
morphology: Spike followed by slow wave complexes
notes: Slow spike-and-wave is characteristic of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Slow spike-and-wave is 2 Hz and irregular; 3 Hz GSW is faster and regular

abretPearl: Slow spike-and-wave (2 Hz) is irregular and characteristic of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It is slower than 3 Hz GSW.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: Standard filters adequate; high LFF may attenuate slow waves

name: Focal Slowing
notes: Focal slowing indicates focal cortical dysfunction.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Focal slowing is regional; diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric
Focal slowing persists in wakefulness; drowsy slowing is state-dependent

abretPearl: Focal slowing is regional and indicates focal cortical dysfunction. It persists across states, unlike drowsy slowing.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF may mask focal slowing; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in referential montages; bipolar may show phase reversals

name: Diffuse Slowing
notes: Diffuse slowing indicates generalized cerebral dysfunction.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric; focal slowing is regional
Diffuse slowing persists in alert wakefulness; drowsy slowing is state-dependent

abretPearl: Diffuse slowing is bilateral and symmetric, indicating generalized cerebral dysfunction. It persists in alert wakefulness, unlike drowsy slowing.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF may mask diffuse slowing; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF

name: Frontal Intermittent Rhythmic Delta Activity (FIRDA)
notes: FIRDA is rhythmic frontal delta activity seen in encephalopathy.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: FIRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; pathologic frontal slowing is irregular and continuous

abretPearl: FIRDA is rhythmic, intermittent frontal delta activity. It is seen in encephalopathy and is distinct from irregular pathologic slowing.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF may mask FIRDA; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in frontal electrodes; referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: May be present in wakefulness or sleep

name: Occipital Intermittent Rhythmic Delta Activity (OIRDA)
notes: OIRDA is rhythmic occipital delta activity seen in encephalopathy, more common in children.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: OIRDA is slower (1–3 Hz) and intermittent; PDR is faster (8–13 Hz) and continuous
OIRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; pathologic occipital slowing is irregular and continuous

abretPearl: OIRDA is rhythmic, intermittent occipital delta activity. It is more common in children and indicates encephalopathy.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF may mask OIRDA; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
eegSettingsSensitivity.montage: Best seen in occipital electrodes; referential montages show field better
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: May be present in wakefulness or sleep

name: Postictal Slowing
duration: Temporary, resolves over minutes to hours
notes: Postictal slowing is temporary slowing seen after seizures.

commonConfusions.distinguishingFeature: Postictal slowing is temporary and resolves; focal slowing is persistent
Postictal slowing is temporary and resolves; diffuse slowing is persistent

abretPearl: Postictal slowing is temporary and resolves over minutes to hours. It indicates recent seizure activity.

eegSettingsSensitivity.filters: High LFF may mask postictal slowing; use standard 0.1–0.3 Hz LFF
eegSettingsSensitivity.state: Present in postictal state; resolves over time
